content.raw:
this broke the homebrew build because there isn't an ignition-cmake1 formula

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=37)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/37/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/37/

I just added aliases for ignition-cmake1, which fixed it

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/commit/8e50a27813226355ed3dc05f8f88bacc2da240ae
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=38)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/38/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/38/

please remember to run and review results of all CI jobs while reviewing pull requests
content.html:
this broke the homebrew build because there isn't an ignition-cmake1 formula

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/37/

I just added aliases for ignition-cmake1, which fixed it

  • https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/commit/8e50a27813226355ed3dc05f8f88bacc2da240ae
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/38/

please remember to run and review results of all CI jobs while reviewing pull requests

update.description:
This PR build on Pull Request #1 to also enable ignition projects to specify component libraries using `ign_add_component(~)`.

There are a few ~~non-backwards-compatible~~ changes between this and Pull Request #1. These changes will be backwards-compatible, but they will print out developer warnings with instructions on how to migrate to the new system. You can find explanations of them in the diff of the migration document, but the short list is:

1. `ign_add_library(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${sources})` is replaced by `ign_create_main_library(SOURCES ${sources})`

2. `ign_install_all_headers(~)` no longer accepts the argument `ADDITIONAL_DIRS` (all subdirectories will be included by default), and instead you may specify subdirectories to exclude using `EXCLUDE_DIRS`.

3. Remove the `ign_install_library()` function completely, because it is no longer used.

~~For now, I'm targeting the `CMakeRefactor` branch to make this easier to review. I'll change it to target `default` after Pull Request #1 is merged.~~
update.title: Creating project components [Ready For Review]

content.raw: yep, verified that components docs are now generated.
content.html: yep, verified that components docs are now generated.

content.raw:
Now that pull request #51 has been merged, it should be mostly okay to merge this one into default.

However, much of our CI is expecting the `default` branch to provide `ign-cmake0`, but this pull request will change that to `ign-cmake1`.

I think before merging this branch, it will be crucial to update all of our CI to use the `ign-cmake0` branch instead of `default`.
content.html:
Now that pull request #51 has been merged, it should be mostly okay to merge this one into default.

However, much of our CI is expecting the default branch to provide ign-cmake0, but this pull request will change that to ign-cmake1.

I think before merging this branch, it will be crucial to update all of our CI to use the ign-cmake0 branch instead of default.

I also test it against all the other libraries that currently use ign-cmake, since it's backwards compatible. @iche033 has been testing it against ign-rendering, and before much longer I'll be testing it against ign-plugin and ign-physics.

content.raw:
I'd say it depends a little bit on the purpose of the library.

If it's an internal library for testing purposes, like gtest, then it should be handled outside the scope of `ign-cmake`, using an ordinary `add_library(~)` command.

If it's a library that we intend to ship and install as part of the project, then it should be added as a component library.

If we have a use case where we want to compile multiple libraries to be part of the "core" of a project but we want to keep them as separate libraries for some reason, we can revisit this macro. I think doing that could create a great deal of confusion, though, if only because it's hard to imagine what kind of naming convention we could even use for those libraries, e.g. `libignition-transport1-core1` and `libignition-transport1-core2`?

So for now, I'd recommend we stick to the design of having one core library and arbitrarily many component libraries. This seems to be a popular pattern among modular library projects.
content.html:
I'd say it depends a little bit on the purpose of the library.

If it's an internal library for testing purposes, like gtest, then it should be handled outside the scope of ign-cmake, using an ordinary add_library(~) command.

If it's a library that we intend to ship and install as part of the project, then it should be added as a component library.

If we have a use case where we want to compile multiple libraries to be part of the "core" of a project but we want to keep them as separate libraries for some reason, we can revisit this macro. I think doing that could create a great deal of confusion, though, if only because it's hard to imagine what kind of naming convention we could even use for those libraries, e.g. libignition-transport1-core1 and libignition-transport1-core2?

So for now, I'd recommend we stick to the design of having one core library and arbitrarily many component libraries. This seems to be a popular pattern among modular library projects.

content.html: Is there any way we can test this pull request? Maybe the branch you mentioned in ign-common?

content.html: Just out of curiosity: is there any way of creating more than one shared library per project using ign-cmake macros? Or should that potential library be a component?

content.raw:
Side note: One alternative approach might be to move all the dependencies above `@PACKAGE_INIT@`. That way we can be confident that `PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR` will be correctly set everywhere in the file after `@PACKAGE_INIT@`.

I don't have a very strong preference between those two options.
content.html:
Side note: One alternative approach might be to move all the dependencies above @PACKAGE_INIT@. That way we can be confident that PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR will be correctly set everywhere in the file after @PACKAGE_INIT@.

I don't have a very strong preference between those two options.

content.raw:
Wow, thanks for figuring this out.

As far as I can figure, your fix is as good of a correction as we're likely to find. It's unfortunate that `@PACKAGE_INIT@` uses a generic variable name (instead of a package-specific variable name), but I'm not terribly interested in coming up with a custom replacement for `@PACKAGE_INIT@`.

Interestingly, the current `default` branch already has this swapped. I guess when I moved the location of `@PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@` in this branch, I just didn't anticipate this issue happening.

Feel free to merge your fix into this branch.
content.html:
Wow, thanks for figuring this out.

As far as I can figure, your fix is as good of a correction as we're likely to find. It's unfortunate that @PACKAGE_INIT@ uses a generic variable name (instead of a package-specific variable name), but I'm not terribly interested in coming up with a custom replacement for @PACKAGE_INIT@.

Interestingly, the current default branch already has this swapped. I guess when I moved the location of @PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@ in this branch, I just didn't anticipate this issue happening.

Feel free to merge your fix into this branch.

content.raw:
[Here's the ign-rendering bitbucket pipeline failure](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/291) revealing this error when trying to build an ign-rendering example

my temporary workaround is to move the block for searching dependency (the one that wraps `@PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@`) to after this line. That worked but I'm not sure if that's the proper fix.
content.html:
Here's the ign-rendering bitbucket pipeline failure revealing this error when trying to build an ign-rendering example

my temporary workaround is to move the block for searching dependency (the one that wraps @PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@) to after this line. That worked but I'm not sure if that's the proper fix.
